review_title: Very structured internship program, but very little work
pros:
1. Good resume builder, no need to elaborate on that. 
2. Provides a platform to reach out to senior scholars and professionals. First, even if you don't work as a research intern, you can get to know about Carnegie scholars and being a carnegie intern already gives you a leg up if you want to further reach out to them. Second, this internship is very structured, and the coordinator will provide interns chances to visit law firm, advocacy firms or big international news agencies, where you may have opportunities to establish connections with professionals working there.
cons: You really need to take initiatives or you might end up sitting in the office all day long without doing much as a summer intern. During the summer most scholars are on semi-vacation, so you won't be given much work to do. If you are a graduate student, I would strongly recommend you to apply for a RA position; other positions will not require advanced degree and it might be a waste of time.

review_title: Wonderful research experience & exposure to think tank industry
job_title: Global Summer Intern in Beijing, Beijing
pros: Even as an intern, I had the chance to work with scholars and policy leaders whose work I have read throughout my academic career. The Beijing foreign policy network -- particularly the expat policy network -- is quite strong, and I had a number of wonderful opportunities to attend speaker events and conferences that augmented my work at the CTC. Upper management was receptive to feedback, and interns were generally allowed to work in their own areas of particular interest.
cons: The intern program was quite large during the summer of 2013, which I think made it a little unwieldy. Some operational points fell through the cracks a little bit (ie performance reviews), but overall the program was very strong.
